Mt |- | align="left" | 2004 || 59.8 || 2,718 || 2,619 || 135 || 371 || 537 |- | align="left" | 2007 || 60.8 || 2,458 || 2,050 || 522 || 373 || 523 |- | align="left" | 2008 || 61.4 || 2,424 || 1,939 || 672 || 372 || 511 |- | align="left" | 2009 || 61.8 || 2,288 || 1,848 || 641 || 352 || 466 |- | align="left" | 2010 || 62.2 || 2,355 || 1,730 || 705 || 357 || 484 |- | align="left" | 2012 || 62.7 || 2,187 || 1,507 || 843 || 346 || 443 |- | align="left" | 2012R || 63.7 || 2,236 || 1,366 || 1,011 || 347 || 457 |- | align="left" | 2013 || 64.1 || 2,221 || 1,280 || 1,099 || 347 || 449 |- | align="left" | 2014 || 64.6 || ? || ? || ? || 304 || 442 |- | align="left" | 2015|| 65.1 || ? || ? || ? || 304 || 404 |- | align="left" | 2016 || 65.7 || ? || 1,465 || ? || 304 || 381 |-style="background:#deffad" | align="left" | Change 2004-16 || 10% || ? || -44% || ? || -18% || -29% |- | align="left" colspan=7 | Mtoe = 11.63 TWh>, Prim. energy includes energy losses that are 2/3 for nuclear power[http://webbshop.cm.se/System/TemplateView.aspx?p=Energimyndigheten&view=default&cat=/Broschyrer&id=e0a2619a83294099a16519a0b5edd26f Energy in Sweden 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016045634/http://webbshop.cm.se/System/TemplateView.aspx?p=Energimyndigheten&view=default&cat=%2FBroschyrer&id=e0a2619a83294099a16519a0b5edd26f |date=16 October 2013 }}, Facts and figures, The Swedish Energy Agency, Table 8 Losses in nuclear power stations Table 9 Nuclear power brutto 2012R = CO2 calculation criteria changed, numbers updated |} As recently as 2004, the UK was a net exporter of energy, however by 2010, more than 25% of UK energy was imported. {| class="wikitable" |+ 2015 fuel taxes, in pounds{{cite |last=Michel |first= Sharon |url=http://wds.iea.org/wds/pdf/EPT_countrynotes.pdf |title=Energy Prices And Taxes, Country Notes, 3rd Quarter 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160119095339/http://wds.iea.org/wds/pdf/EPT_countrynotes.pdf |archive-date=19 January 2016 |page=118 |publisher=[[International Energy Agency]] |date= 2015}} ! || Diesel || Gasoline || colspan=2 | Natural gas || Coal || Electricity |- ! per unit || [[litre]] || [[litre]] || [[Cubic metre|m3]] || [[Kilowatt hour#Multiples|MWh]] || tonne || [[Kilowatt hour#Multiples|MWh]] |- | [[Excise]] || ? || 0.4682 || || || || |- | Environment || || || || 1.93 || 15.12 || 5.54 |} === Energy in Scotland === Scotland cut climate emissions by around 46% between 1990 and 2014.[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/jun/14/scotland-beats-climate-emissions-reductions-target-six-years-early Scotland beats climate emissions reductions target six years early] Guardian 16 June 2016 Scotland aims to have a carbon-free electricity sector based on renewable energy sources by 2032. Scotland also aims to repair 250,000 hectares of degraded [[peatland]]s, which store a total of 1.7 gigatonnes of CO2. [https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/jan/19/scotland-sets-ambitious-goal-of-66-emissions-cut-within-15-years Scotland sets ambitious goal of 66% emissions cut within 15 years] Guardian 19 January 2017 ==Fossil fuels== {{main article|List of active coal fired power stations in the United Kingdom}} [[File:Fossil fuel consumption in the United Kingdom.svg|thumb|Fossil fuel consumption in the UK. Through the 90s, coal use declined while natural gas use increased.]] During 2008, the total energy consumed in the United Kingdom was 234.4 million [[Oil equivalent|tonnes of oil equivalent]] (which is around 9.85 EJ = 9.85×1018J).[http://www.chaucer.ac.uk/ctsshared/geography/AS%20&%20A%20Level/Year%2013%20Geography/Unit%203%20Contested%20Planet/Energy%20Security/Prereleased%20Booklet%20January%202013/GeographyofPlaces.docx UK Energy Consumption Figures 2008] Department of Energy and Climate Change Concerns over [[peak oil]] have been raised by high-profile voices in the United Kingdom such as [[Sir David King]]{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2010/jun/09/sir-david-king-dwindling-oil-supplies | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Top scientist says politicians have 'heads in the sand' over oil | first=David | last=Adam | date=9 June 2010}} and the Industry Task-Force on Peak Oil and Energy Security.{{cite web|url=http://peakoiltaskforce.net/ |title=Latest from the Taskforce | The Peak Oil Group |publisher=Peakoiltaskforce.net |date=23 May 2011 |accessdate=5 October 2013}} The latter's 2010 report states that "The next five years will see us face another crunch - the oil crunch. This time, we do have the chance to prepare. The challenge is to use that time well." ([[Sir Richard Branson]] and [[Ian Marchant (businessman)|Ian Marchant]]).The Oil Crunch: A wake-up call for the UK economy, Second report of the UK Industry Taskforce on Peak Oil & Energy Security (ITPOES) February 2010 ===Natural gas=== United Kingdom produced 60% of its consumed [[natural gas]] in 2010. In five years the United Kingdom moved from almost gas self-sufficient (see [[North Sea Gas]]) to 40% gas import in 2010. Gas was almost 40% of total primary energy supply (TPES) and electricity more than 45% in 2010. Underground storage was about 5% of annual demand and more than 10% of net imports. There is an alternative fuel obligation in the United Kingdom.[http://iea.org/papers/2011/gas_emergency_policy.pdf Gas emergency policy: Where do IEA countries stand?] IEA 25 May 2011, figures (see [[Renewable Transport Fuel Obligation]]) Gasfields include [[Amethyst gasfield]], [[Armada gasfield]], [[Easington Catchment Area]], [[East Knapton]], [[Everest gasfield]] and [[Rhum gasfield]]. A gas leak occurred in March 2012 at the [[Elgin-Franklin fields]], where about 200,000 cubic metres of gas was escaping every day. [[Total S.A.|Total]] missed out on about £83m of potential income.[https://www.theguardian.com/business/2013/mar/11/elgin-north-sea-gas-platform-reopens Elgin North Sea gas platform resumes production almost year after leak] The Guardian 11 March 2013 ==Electricity supply== [[File:UK Electricity demand and wind suply graph 5.jpg|thumb|A graph showing UK electricity demand mapped over electricity supplied to the grid by wind power since 2011.]] {{main article|Electricity sector in the United Kingdom}} [[File:UK Historical Net Electricity supplied.PNG|thumb|Electricity supplied (net) 1948 to 2008{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/digest-of-uk-energy-statistics-dukes |title=Digest of UK energy statistics: 60th Anniversary Report |accessdate=16 December 2013}}]] [[File:UK electricity production by source.png|thumb|UK electricity production by source 1980-2017[http://www.eia.gov/cfapps/ipdbproject/iedindex3.cfm?tid=2&pid=2&aid=12&cid=all,&syid=1980&eyid=2011&unit=BKWH Internation Energy Statistics]{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/513244/Press_Notice_March_2016.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=14 August 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160703213024/https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/513244/Press_Notice_March_2016.pdf |archivedate=3 July 2016 |df=dmy }}{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/296183/pn_march_14.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=14 August 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161008175750/https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/296183/pn_march_14.pdf |archivedate=8 October 2016 |df=dmy }}https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/electricity-section-5-energy-trends]] With the development of the [[National Grid (UK)|national grid]], the switch to using electricity, United Kingdom electricity consumption increased by around 150% between the [[World War II|post war]] [[nationalisation]] of the industry in 1948 and the mid-1960s. During the 1960s growth slowed as the market became [[Market saturation|saturated]]. The United Kingdom is planning to [[Decarbonisation Measures in Proposed UK Electricity Market Reform|reform its electricity market]]. It plans to introduce a capacity mechanism and contracts for difference to encourage the building of new generation. ===Fuel sources=== During the 1940s some 90% of the [[Electricity generation|generating capacity]] was fired by [[coal]], with [[Petroleum|oil]] providing most of the remainder. [[File:Battersea Powerstation - Across Thames - London - 020504.jpg|thumb|right|The former [[Battersea Power Station]]]] The United Kingdom started to develop a [[Nuclear power|nuclear generating]] capacity in the 1950s, with [[Calder Hall nuclear power station|Calder Hall]] being connected to the grid on 27 August 1956. Though the production of [[weapons-grade]] [[plutonium]] was the main reason behind this [[power station]], other civil stations followed, and 26% of the nation's electricity was generated from nuclear power at its peak in 1997. Despite the flow of North Sea oil from the mid-1970s, oil fuelled generation remained relatively small and continued to decline. Starting in 1993, and continuing through the 1990s, a combination of factors led to a so-called [[Dash for Gas]], during which the use of coal was scaled back in favour of gas-fuelled generation. This was sparked by the privatisation of the [[National Coal Board]], [[British Gas plc|British Gas]] and the [[Central Electricity Generating Board]]; the introduction of laws facilitating competition within the energy markets; and the availability of cheap gas from the [[North Sea]]. In 1990 just 1.09% of all gas consumed in the country was used in electricity generation; by 2004 the figure was 30.25%.[http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20100304141706/http://www.berr.gov.uk/files/file10738.pdf UK Energy in Brief July 2005], DTI statistics By 2004, coal use in power stations had fallen to 50.5 million tonnes, representing 82.4% of all coal used in 2004 (a fall of 43.6% compared to 1980 levels), though up slightly from its low in 1999. On several occasions in May 2016, Britain burned no coal for electricity for the first time since 1882.{{cite web|url=https://next.ft.com/content/fc2c8d12-191d-11e6-bb7d-ee563a5a1cc1|title=Britain passes historic milestone with first days of coal-free power|work=Financial Times|accessdate=19 June 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2016/05/10/britain-gets-no-power-from-coal-for-first-time-on-record/|title=Britain gets no power from coal for 'first time on record'|date=10 May 2016|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=19 June 2016}} On 21 April 2017, Britain went a full day without using coal power for the first time since the [[Industrial Revolution]], according to the [[National_Grid_(Great_Britain)|National Grid]].{{cite web|title=First coal-free day in Britain since Industrial Revolution|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-39675418|website=BBC News|date=22 April 2017|access-date=22 April 2017}} From the mid-1990s new [[renewable energy]] sources began to contribute to the electricity generated, adding to a small [[hydroelectricity]] generating capacity. In 2016, total electricity production stood at 357 [[TWh]] (down from a peak of 385 TWh in 2005), generated from the following sources:{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/642716/Chapter_1.pdf|title=UK Energy Statistics, 2016|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/energy-chapter-1-digest-of-united-kingdom-energy-statistics-dukes|title=Digest of UK Energy Statistics - Department of Business, Energy & Industrial Strategy - GOV.UK|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=beis.gov.uk|accessdate=24 October 2017}} [[File:Oil platform.jpeg|thumb|right|A typical offshore oil/gas platform|225x225px]] *Gas: 40.2% (0.05% in 1990) *Nuclear: 20.1% (19% in 1990) *Wind: 10.6% (0% in 1990), of which: :*Onshore Wind: 5.7% :*Offshore Wind: 4.9% *Coal: 8.6% (67% in 1990) *Bio-Energy: 8.4% (0% in 1990) *Solar: 2.8% (0% in 1990) *Hydroelectric: 1.5% (2.6% in 1990) *Oil and other: 7.8% (12% in 1990) The [[Energy policy of the United Kingdom|UK Government energy policy]] had targeted a total contribution from renewables to achieve 10% by 2010, but it was not until 2012 that this figure was exceeded; renewable energy sources supplied 11.3% (41.3 TWh) of the electricity generated in the United Kingdom in 2012.{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/renewable-sources-of-energy-chapter-6-digest-of-united-kingdom-energy-statistics-dukes|title=Department of Energy and Climate Change: Annual tables: ‘Digest of UK energy statistics’ (DUKES) - Chapter 6: Renewable Sources of energy|accessdate=1 September 2013}} The [[Scottish Government]] has a target of generating 17% to 18% of [[Scotland|Scotland's]] electricity from renewables by 2010,http://www.scotland.gov.uk/Resource/Doc/1050/0002275.pdf rising to 40% by 2020.{{cite web|url=http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2003/03/3412 |title=Ministers confirm 40 per cent renewables target |publisher=Scotland.gov.uk |date=25 March 2003 |accessdate=5 October 2013}} ===UK 'energy gap'=== [[File:UK Electricity Capacity Margin.PNG|thumb|UK Electricity Capacity Margin{{cite web|author=[[Department of Energy and Climate Change]] |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/department-of-energy-climate-change/series/energy-consumption-in-the-uk |title=Energy consumption in the UK|publisher=GOV.UK |date=25 July 2013 |accessdate=5 October 2013}}]] In the early years of the 2000s, concerns grew over the prospect of an 'energy gap' in United Kingdom generating capacity. This was forecast to arise because it was expected that a number of [[fossil fuel power plant|coal fired power stations]] would close due to being unable to meet the clean air requirements of the [[Large Combustion Plant Directive|European Large Combustion Plant Directive]] (directive 2001/80/EC).[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX:32001L0080 Directive 2001/80/EC ] In addition, the United Kingdom's remaining [[Magnox]] nuclear stations were to have closed by 2015. The oldest [[Advanced gas-cooled reactor|AGR]] nuclear power station has had its life extended by ten years,{{citation|url=http://www.british-energy.com/article.php?article=99 |title=10-year life extension at Dungeness B nuclear power station|date=15 September 2005|publisher=[[British Energy]]|accessdate=19 June 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060322013831/http://www.british-energy.com/article.php?article=99 |archivedate = 22 March 2006}} and it was likely many of the others could be life-extended, reducing the potential gap suggested by the current accounting closure dates of between 2014 and 2023 for the AGR power stations.{{citation|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/main.jhtml?xml=/money/2006/06/12/ccnuke12.xml|title=Nuclear stations may stay on line to bridge the gap|author=Stephen Seawright|date=13 June 2006|publisher=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=30 August 2008 | location=London}} A report from the industry in 2005 forecast that, without action to fill the gap, there would be a 20% shortfall in electricity generation capacity by 2015. Similar concerns were raised by a report published in 2000 by the [[Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution]] ''([https://web.archive.org/web/20070220162203/http://www.rcep.org.uk/newenergy.htm Energy - The Changing Climate]''). The [[Energy policy of the United Kingdom#2006 Energy Review|2006 Energy Review]] attracted considerable press coverage - in particular in relation to the prospect of constructing a new generation of nuclear power stations, in order to prevent the rise in carbon dioxide emissions that would arise if other conventional power stations were to be built. Among the public, according to a November 2005 poll conducted by [[YouGov]] for [[Deloitte]], 35% of the population expect that by 2020 the majority of electricity generation will come from renewable energy (more than double the government's target, and far larger than the 5.5% generated as of 2008),[http://www.newenergyworldnetwork.com/renewable-energy-news/news_type/policy-by_technology-new-news/renewables-rise-to-55-per-cent-of-total-uk-output-according-to-department-of-energy-and-climate-change.html], page 23, ''[[Department of Energy and Climate Change]]'', published 2009-07-30, accessed 28 August 2009 23% expect that the majority will come from nuclear power, and only 18% that the majority will come from fossil fuels. 92% thought the Government should do more to explore alternative power generation technologies to reduce carbon emissions.[http://www.deloitte.com/dtt/press_release/0,1014,sid=2834&cid=102273,00.html Support for nuclear and renewable energy], [[Deloitte]], published 2005-12-02, retrieved 17 March 2007 In June 2013, the industry regulator [[Ofgem]] warned that the UK's energy sector faces "unprecedented challenges" and that "spare electricity power production capacity could fall to 2% by 2015, increasing the risk of blackouts". Proposed solutions "could include negotiating with major power users for them to [[National Grid Reserve Service|reduce demand during peak times]] in return for payment".{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-23081695 |title=BBC News - Ofgem warns danger of power shortages has increased |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=27 June 2013 |accessdate=5 October 2013}} ===Plugging the energy gap=== The first move to plug the United Kingdom's projected energy gap was the construction of the conventionally gas-fired [[Langage Power Station]] and [[Marchwood Power Station]] which became operational in 2010. In 2007, proposals for the construction of two new coal-fired power stations were announced, in [[Tilbury]], Essex and in [[Kingsnorth (Medway)|Kingsnorth]], Kent. They were to be the first coal-fired stations to be built in the United Kingdom in 20 years.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/6444373.stm Plans for two coal power stations announced], [[BBC]], published 2007-03-14, accessed 17 March 2007. No power station at Tilbury was built and the plans for a new Kingsnorth coal powered station were later shelved.{{cite news |title=Kingsnorth power station plans shelved by E.ON |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2009/oct/07/eon-cancels-kingsnorth-power-station |publisher=Guardian |date=7 October 2009 |accessdate=7 October 2009 | location=London | first=David | last=Adam}} Beyond these new plants, there were a number of options that might have been used to provide the new generating capacity, while minimising [[carbon emission]]s and producing less residues and contamination. [[Fossil fuel power plant]]s might provide a solution if there was a satisfactory and economical way of reducing their carbon emissions. [[Carbon capture and storage|Carbon capture]] might provide a way of doing this; however the technology is relatively untried and costs are relatively high. As of 2006 there were no power plants in operation with a full carbon capture and storage system, and as of 2018 the situation is little better. ===Energy gap disappears=== However, due to reducing demand in the [[late-2000s recession]] removing any medium term gap, and high gas prices, in 2011 and 2012 over 2 GW of older, less efficient, gas generation plant was mothballed.{{cite news |url=http://interfaxenergy.com/natural-gas-news-analysis/european/uk-power-plants-mothballed-on-higher-gas-prices/ |title=UK power plants mothballed on higher gas prices |author=Andreas Walstad |work=National Gas Daily |publisher=Interfax |date=2 August 2011 |accessdate=9 April 2012}}{{cite news |url=http://www.argusmediagroup.com/News/Article?id=789586 |title=Centrica idles gas-fired plant amid low spark spreads |publisher=Argus Media |date=12 March 2012 |accessdate=9 April 2012}} In 2011 electricity demand dropped 4%, and about 6.5 GW of additional gas-fired capacity was added over 2011 and 2012. Early in 2012 the reserve margin stood at the high level of 32%.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-02-23/centrica-may-mothball-more-gas-plants-as-capacity-trims-profits.html |title=Centrica May Mothball More Gas Plants as Capacity Trims Profits |author=Kari Lundgren |publisher=Bloomberg |date=23 February 2012 |accessdate=9 April 2012}} An important factor in reduced electrical demand in recent years has come from the [[phasing out of incandescent light bulbs]] and a switch to [[compact fluorescent]] and [[LED_lamp|LED lighting]]. Research by the University of Oxford{{cite news|title=Peak Light Bulb|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg22129501.900-electricity-use-drops-as-uk-passes-peak-light-bulb.html|newspaper=New Scientist|date=4 January 2014|page=4}} has shown that the average annual electrical consumption for lighting in a UK home fell from 720 kWh in 1997 to 508 kWh in 2012. Between 2007 and 2015, the UK's peak electrical demand fell from 61.5 GW to 52.7.GW.{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/540933/Chapter_5_web.pdf |title= UK Electricity production and demand 2015 |page=124}} ===Regional differences=== {{See also|Energy policy of Scotland}} While in some ways limited by [[Reserved and excepted matters|which powers]] are [[Devolution|devolved]], the four countries of the United Kingdom have different energy mixes and ambitions. [[Scotland]] currently has a target of 80% of electricity from renewables by 2020, which was increased from an original ambition of 50% by 2020 after it exceeded its interim target of 31 per cent by 2011.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-11395734 | work=BBC News | title=New target for Scottish renewable energy | date=23 September 2010}} It has a quarter of the EU's estimated offshore wind potential,{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/8447317.stm | work=BBC News | title=New wind farm contracts announced | date=8 January 2010}} and is at the forefront of testing various marine energy systems.{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/green-living/marine-energy-projects-approved-for-scotland-1922370.html | location=London | work=The Independent | title=Marine energy projects approved for Scotland | first=Kunal | last=Dutta | date=17 March 2010}} ===Nuclear=== {{Main article|Nuclear power in the United Kingdom}} [[File:Heysham Power Station, from dockside.jpg|thumb|Heysham nuclear power stations]] Britain's fleet of operational reactors consists of 14 advanced gas-cooled reactors on six discrete sites, along with two Magnox units at Wylfa, and one PWR unit at Sizewell B. Overall, the installed nuclear capacity in the United Kingdom is between 10 and 11 GW.{{cite web|author=Marion Brünglinghaus, ENS, European Nuclear Society |url=http://www.euronuclear.org/info/encyclopedia/n/nuclear-power-plant-world-wide.htm |title=Nuclear power plants, world-wide |publisher=Euronuclear.org |date= |accessdate=5 October 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.world-nuclear.org/info/inf84.html |title=Nuclear Power in the United Kingdom |UK Nuclear Energy |publisher=World-nuclear.org |date= |accessdate=5 October 2013}} In addition, the UK experimented with Fast Breeder reactor technologies at Dounreay in Scotland, however the last fast breeder (with 250MWe of capacity) was shut down in 1994.{{cite web|url=http://www.dounreay.com/decommissioning/prototype-fast-reactor |title=Dounreay Site Restoration Ltd - Prototype Fast Reactor |publisher=Dounreay.com |date=18 August 2008 |accessdate=5 October 2013}} While nuclear power does not produce significant carbon dioxide in generation (though the [[construction]], [[mining]], [[Radioactive waste|waste handling and disposal]], and [[Nuclear decommissioning|decommissioning]] do generate some carbon emissions), it raises other environmental and security concerns. Despite this, it has enormous potential for generating electricity, when it is taken into consideration that uranium could last up to a hundred years.{{cite book |publisher = [[OECD]] Publishing |url = http://www.oecdbookshop.org/oecd/display.asp?sf1=identifiers&st1=9789264047662 |title = Uranium 2007 – Resources, Production and Demand |date = 17 June 2008 |isbn = 978-92-64-04766-2 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090130092151/http://www.oecdbookshop.org/oecd/display.asp?sf1=identifiers&st1=9789264047662 |archivedate = 30 January 2009 |df = dmy-all }} However, even with changes to the [[planning permission|planning system]] to speed applications, there are doubts over whether the necessary timescale could be met, and over the financial viability of nuclear power with present oil and gas prices. With no nuclear plants having been constructed since [[Sizewell B nuclear power station|Sizewell B]] in 1995, there are also likely to be capacity issues within the native nuclear industry. The existing privatised nuclear supplier, [[British Energy]], had been in financial trouble in 2004. In October 2010 the coalition [[Government of the United Kingdom|British Government]] gave the go-ahead for the construction of up to eight new nuclear power plants.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/energy/8070810/Eight-new-nuclear-power-stations-despite-safety-and-clean-up-concerns.html Eight new nuclear power stations despite safety and clean-up concerns] Telegraph, published 2010-10-18, accessed 29 March 2011 However, the [[Scottish Government]], with the backing of the [[Scottish Parliament]], has stated that no new nuclear power stations will be constructed in [[Scotland]].{{cite web|title=Answers to your questions on energy in Scotland|url=http://www.scotland.gov.uk/Topics/Business-Industry/Energy/Facts/faqs|publisher=The Scottish Government|accessdate=5 May 2011}}{{cite web|title=Official Report 17 January 2008|url=http://www.scottish.parliament.uk/business/officialReports/meetingsParliament/or-08/sor0117-02.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090620205946/http://www.scottish.parliament.uk/business/officialReports/meetingsParliament/or-08/sor0117-02.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=20 June 2009|publisher=The Scottish Parliament|accessdate=5 May 2011}} In March 2012, [[E.ON UK]] and [[RWE npower]] announced they would be pulling out of developing new nuclear power plants, placing the future of nuclear power in the United Kingdom in doubt.{{cite web |url=http://www.scotsman.com/the-scotsman/scotland/nuclear-disaster-casts-shadow-over-future-of-uk-s-energy-plans-1-2205614 |title=Nuclear disaster casts shadow over future of UK’s energy plans |author=David Maddox |date=30 March 2012 |work=The Scotsman }} There was an 11% increase in the use of nuclear power in 2011, which helped to bring greenhouse gas emissions down 7% on the previous year.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2012/mar/29/uk-greenhouse-gas-emissions-2011 | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Adam | last=Vaughan | title=UK greenhouse gas emissions down 7% in 2011 | date=29 March 2012}} ===Renewable energy=== {{main article|Renewable energy in the United Kingdom}} In 2007, the United Kingdom Government agreed to an overall European Union target of generating 20% of the European Union's energy supply from renewable sources by 2020. Each European Union member state was given its own allocated target; for the United Kingdom it is 15%. This was formalised in January 2009 with the passage of the EU [[Renewables Directive]]. As renewable heat and fuel production in the United Kingdom are at extremely low bases, [[RenewableUK]] estimates that this will require 35–40% of the United Kingdom's electricity to be generated from renewable sources by that date,{{cite web|last=McKenna |first=John |url=http://www.nce.co.uk/wind-power-chancellor-urged-to-use-budget-to-aid-ailing-developers/5200267.article |title=New Civil Engineer – Wind power: Chancellor urged to use budget to aid ailing developers |publisher=Nce.co.uk |date=8 April 2009 |accessdate=5 October 2013}} to be met largely by 33–35 GW of installed wind capacity. The total of all renewable electricity sources provided for 14.9% of the electricity generated in the United Kingdom in 2013,{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/renewable-sources-of-energy-chapter-6-digest-of-united-kingdom-energy-statistics-dukes|title=Department of Energy and Climate Change: Annual tables: ‘Digest of UK energy statistics’ (DUKES) - Chapter 6: Renewable Sources of energy|accessdate=13 April 2015}} reaching 53.7 TWh of electricity generated. In June 2017 renewables plus nuclear generated more UK power than gas and coal together for the first time. In 2017 new offshore wind power became cheaper than new nuclear power for the first time.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-42495883 |title=UK enjoyed 'greenest year for electricity ever' in 2017 |work=BBC News |date=28 December 2017 |accessdate=6 July 2018}} ====Wind power==== {{Main article|Wind power in the United Kingdom}} {{Further |Wind power in the European Union}} [[File:Pretty flamingos - geograph.org.uk - 578705.jpg|thumb|upright|Burbo Bank Offshore Wind Farm]] In December 2007, the United Kingdom Government announced plans for a massive expansion of wind energy production, by conducting a Strategic Environmental Assessment of up to 25 GW worth of wind farm offshore sites in preparation for a new round of development. These proposed sites were in addition to the 8 GW worth of sites already awarded in the 2 earlier rounds of site allocations, Round 1 in 2001 and Round 2 in 2003. Taken together it was estimated that this would result in the construction of over 7,000 offshore wind turbines.{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/main.jhtml?xml=/earth/2008/06/25/eawindfarms125.xml | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London | first=Janet | last=Daley | title=Earth}} Wind power delivers a growing fraction of the energy in the United Kingdom and at the beginning of November 2018, wind power in the United Kingdom consisted of nearly 10,000 wind turbines with a total installed capacity of just over 20 [[gigawatts]]: 12,254 [[megawatts]] of onshore capacity and 7,897 megawatts of offshore capacity.{{cite web |last1=Association |first1=RenewableUK |title=Wind Energy Statistics - RenewableUK |url=https://www.renewableuk.com/page/UKWEDhome |website=www.renewableuk.com |accessdate=31 October 2018 |language=en}} ====Solar==== [[File:BedZED 2007.jpg|thumb|Solar panels on the [[BedZED]] development in the [[London Borough of Sutton]]]] {{Main article|Solar power in the United Kingdom}} At the end of 2011, there were 230,000 solar power projects in the United Kingdom,{{cite web |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2012/02/09/uk-solar-tariff-idUKTRE8180XS20120209 |title=UK wants sustained cuts to solar panel tariffs |author=Yeganeh Torbati |date=9 February 2012 |work=Reuters }} with a total installed generating capacity of 750 [[megawatts]] (MW).{{cite web |url=http://www.epia.org/index.php?id=18 |title=Market Report 2011 |author=European Photovoltaic Industry Association |year=2012 |work= |access-date=26 April 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140702040515/http://www.epia.org/index.php?id=18 |archive-date=2 July 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} By February 2012 the installed capacity had reached 1,000 MW.{{cite web |url= |title=UK hits one GW of PV capacity |author=Jonathan Gifford |date=23 February 2012 |work=PV Magazine }} [[Solar power]] use has increased very rapidly in recent years, albeit from a small base, as a result of reductions in the cost of [[photovoltaic]] (PV) panels, and the introduction of a [[Feed-in tariff]] (FIT) subsidy in April 2010. In 2012, the government said that 4 million homes across the UK will be powered by the sun within eight years,{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2012/feb/09/solar-power-ambition-uk |title=Greg Barker: 4m homes will be solar-powered by 2020 |author=Fiona Harvey |date=9 February 2012 |work= }} representing 22,000 MW of installed solar power capacity by 2020. ====Biofuels==== {{main article|Biofuel in the United Kingdom}} Gas from [[sewage]] and [[landfill]] ([[biogas]]) has already been exploited in some areas. In 2004 it provided 129.3 GW·h (up 690% from 1990 levels), and was the UK's leading renewable energy source, representing 39.4% of all renewable energy produced (including hydro).[http://www.dti.gov.uk/files/file10738.pdf DTI figures] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061209070902/http://www.dti.gov.uk/files/file10738.pdf |date=9 December 2006 }} The UK has committed to a target of 10.3% of renewable energy in transport to comply with the [http://bioenergywiki.net/Renewable_Energy_Directive Renewable Energy Directive] of the European Union but has [http://bioenergywiki.net/Policy_implementation_in_the_United_Kingdom not yet implemented legislation] to meet this target. Other [[biofuel]]s can provide a close-to-carbon-neutral energy source, if locally grown. In [[South America]] and [[Asia]], the production of biofuels for export has in some cases resulted in significant ecological damage, including the clearing of [[rainforest]]. In 2004 biofuels provided 105.9 GW·h, 38% of it [[wood]]. This represented an increase of 500% from 1990.[http://www.dti.gov.uk/files/file10738.pdf (DTI figures)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061209070902/http://www.dti.gov.uk/files/file10738.pdf |date=9 December 2006 }} ====Geothermal power==== {{main article|Geothermal power in the United Kingdom}} Investigations into the exploitation of [[Geothermal power in the United Kingdom]], prompted by the [[1973 oil crisis]], were abandoned as fuel prices fell. Only one scheme is operational, in [[Southampton]]. In 2004 it was announced that a further scheme would be built to heat the UK's first geothermal energy [[model village]] near [[Eastgate, County Durham|Eastgate]], [[County Durham]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/4096231.stm 'Hot rocks' found at cement plant] ====Hydroelectric==== {{main article|Hydroelectricity in the United Kingdom}} [[File:Dinorwig Power Station.jpg|thumb|The [[Dinorwig Power Station]] lower reservoir, a 1,800 MW pumped-storage hydroelectric scheme, in north Wales, and the largest hydroelectric power station in the UK]] As of 2012, [[hydroelectric power]] stations in the United Kingdom accounted for 1.67 GW of installed electrical generating capacity, being 1.9% of the UK's total generating capacity and 14% of UK's [[renewable energy]] generating capacity. Annual electricity production from such schemes is approximately 5,700 GWh, being about 1.5% of the UK's total electricity production.{{cite web|url=http://www.decc.gov.uk/en/content/cms/meeting_energy/hydro/use/use.aspx|title=Department of Energy and Climate Change: UK use of Hydroelectricity|accessdate=23 September 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121127194425/http://www.decc.gov.uk/en/content/cms/meeting_energy/hydro/use/use.aspx|archivedate=27 November 2012|df=dmy-all}} There are also [[Pumped-storage hydroelectricity|pumped-storage]] power stations in the UK. These power stations are net consumers of electrical energy however they contribute to balancing the grid, which can facilitate renewable generation elsewhere, for example by 'soaking up' surplus renewable output at off-peak times and release the energy when it is required. ==Cogeneration== {{main article|District_heating#United_Kingdom}} [[File:Pimlico accumulator tower 1.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[District heating]] [[Accumulator (energy)|accumulator]] tower, [[Pimlico]]]] [[Cogeneration|Combined heat and power plants]], where 'waste' hot water from generating is used for [[district heating]], are also a well tried technology in other parts of Europe. While it heats about 50% of all houses in [[Denmark]], [[Finland]], [[Poland]], [[Sweden]] and [[Slovakia]], it currently only plays a small role in the United Kingdom. It has, however, been rising, with total generation standing at 27.9 TWh by 2008. This consisted of 1,439 predominantly gas-fired schemes with a total CHP electrical generating capacity of 5.47 GW, and contributing 7% of the UK's electricity supply. Heat generation utilisation has fallen however from a peak of 65 TWh in 1991 to 49 TWh in 2012. ==Energy research== Historically, public sector support for energy research and development in the United Kingdom has been provided by a variety of bodies with little co-ordination between them. Problems experienced have included poor continuity of funding, and the availability of funding for certain parts of the research—development—commercialisation process but not others. Levels of public funding have also been low by international standards, and funding by the private sector has also been limited. Research in the area of energy is carried out by a number of public and private sector bodies: The [[Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council]] funds an energy programme[http://www.epsrc.ac.uk/ResearchFunding/Programmes/energy/default.htm], [[Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council]] spanning energy and climate change research. It aims to "develop, embrace and exploit sustainable, low carbon and/or energy efficient technologies and systems" to enable the United Kingdom "to meet the Government’s energy and environmental targets by 2020". Its research includes renewable, conventional, nuclear and [[Fusion power|fusion]] electricity supply as well as energy efficiency, [[fuel poverty]] and other topics. Since being established in 2004, the UK Energy Research Centre[http://www.ukerc.ac.uk/content/view/11/86/], UK Energy Research Centre carries out research into demand reduction, future sources of energy, infrastructure and supply, energy systems, sustainability and materials for advanced energy systems. The [[United Kingdom Energy Technologies Institute|Energy Technologies Institute]], expected to begin operating in 2008, is to 'accelerate the development of secure, reliable and cost-effective low-carbon energy technologies towards commercial deployment'. In relation to buildings, the Building Research Establishment[http://www.bre.co.uk/keyservice.jsp?sid=360], [[Building Research Establishment]] carries out some research into energy conservation. There is currently international research being conducted into [[fusion power]]. The [[ITER]] reactor is currently being constructed at [[Cadarache]] in France. The United Kingdom contributes towards this project through membership of the [[European Union]]. Prior to this, an experimental fusion reactor (the [[Joint European Torus]]) had been built at [[Culham]] in Oxfordshire. ==Energy efficiency== The United Kingdom government has instituted several policies intended to promote an increase in efficient energy use. These include the roll out of [[smart meters]], the [[Green Deal]], the [[CRC Energy Efficiency Scheme]], the Energy Savings Opportunity Scheme{{cite web |url=http://www.carbontrust.com/esos |title=ESOS: Energy Savings Opportunity Scheme |publisher=The Carbon Trust |accessdate=9 July 2014 }} and [[Climate Change Agreement]]s. In tackling the energy trilemma, [[Efficient energy use|saving energy]] is the cheapest of all measures. The Guardian newspaper reported that in 2012 that by 2050, Germany projects a 25% drop in electricity demand: the UK projects a rise of up to 66%. [[Member of Parliament|MP]] and [[Secretary of State for Energy and Climate Change]] [[Ed Davey]] pointed out in November 2012 that a modest 10% reduction in 2030 means five fewer power stations and £4bn cut from bills.[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/damian-carrington-blog/2012/nov/29/energy-bill-efficiency-davey Energy saving finally gets serious as alarm bells wake ministers] - Ed Davey has plugged a gaping hole in coalition energy policy by proposing serious if very belated - energy efficiency measures, but the overall policy remains a risky bet, The Guardian 29 November 2012 The UK government has implemented measures aimed at cutting the UK's energy use by 11% (around 196TWh) by 2020. If achieved, this improvement would be sufficient to replace 22 UK power stations, while possibly providing a boost to the economy and living standards.[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2012/nov/12/energy-efficiency-uk-close-power-stations Energy efficiency could replace 22 UK power stations] Guardian 12 November 2012 ==Climate change== The [[Committee on Climate Change]] publishes an annual progress report in respect to control the [[climate change in the United Kingdom]]. ==See also== {{Portal|Energy|Sustainable development|United Kingdom}} * [[Compulsory Stock Obligation]] * [[Energy policy of the United Kingdom]] * [[Economy of the United Kingdom]] * [[Energy conservation in the United Kingdom]] * [[Energy switching services in the UK]] * [[Greenhouse gas emissions by the United Kingdom]] * [[Meter Point Administration Number]] * [[Renewable energy in the United Kingdom]] * [[List of renewable energy topics by country|Renewable energy by country]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.ukerc.ac.uk/ UK Energy Research Centre] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/bsp/hi/pdfs/14_06_06_powerstations.pdf Map of United Kingdom power stations] *[http://www.enerdata.net/enerdatauk/knowledge/eshop/market-report-by-category.php Energy Analyses in UK] *[http://www.oilandgasinfrastructure.com/home/oilandgaseurope/oilandgasunitedkingdom Map of the UK oil and gas infrastructure] *[https://transparency.entsoe.eu/ ENTSO-E Transparency Platform] {{Energy in the United Kingdom|uncollapsed}} {{Europe topic|Energy in}} {{United Kingdom topics}} {{Economy of the United Kingdom}} [[Category:Energy in the United Kingdom| ]] [[Category:Energy by country in the European Union|United Kingdom]]

{{Global surveillance}} {{about||later global surveillance disclosures|Global surveillance disclosures (2013–present)}} [[Global surveillance]] refers to the practice of [[globalization|globalized]] [[mass surveillance]] on entire populations across national borders.<ref>{{cite book|last=Webb|first=Maureen|title=Illusions of Security: Global Surveillance and Democracy in the Post-9/11 World|year=2007|publisher=[[City Lights Books]]|location=San Francisco|isbn=0872864766|edition=1.}}</ref> Although its existence was first revealed in the 1970s and led legislators to attempt to curb domestic spying by the [[National Security Agency]] (NSA), it did not receive sustained public attention until the existence of '''[[ECHELON]]''' was revealed in the 1980s and confirmed in the 1990s.<ref name="echelon"/> In 2013 it gained substantial worldwide media attention due to the [[global surveillance disclosure]] by [[Edward Snowden]].<ref name="gellman12wapo">{{cite news|last=[[Barton Gellman]]|title=Edward Snowden, after months of NSA revelations, says his mission’s accomplished|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/edward-snowden-after-months-of-nsa-revelations-says-his-missions-accomplished/2013/12/23/49fc36de-6c1c-11e3-a523-fe73f0ff6b8d_story.html|date=24 December 2013|publisher=''The Washington Post''|accessdate=25 December 2013|quote=Taken together, the revelations have brought to light a global surveillance system that cast off many of its historical restraints after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. Secret legal authorities empowered the NSA to sweep in the telephone, Internet and location records of whole populations.}}</ref>
==History== {|class="infobox bordered" style="font-size:95%; width:20em;" ! style="font-size:120%; text-align:center; padding:5px 0;" | '''Timeline''' |- | * {{Timeline-event |date='''{{Start date|1975}}''' |event= The [[Church Committee]] investigated the [[National Security Agency|NSA]] and passed legislation intended to curb domestic spying.<ref>{{cite web|last=Schorr|first=Daniel|title=A Brief History of the NSA|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5176847|publisher=NPR|accessdate=2 February 2014|date=29 January 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ewen MacAskill, Julian Borger and Glenn Greenwald|title=The National Security Agency: surveillance giant with eyes on America|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/06/national-security-agency-surveillance|publisher=''The Guardian''|accessdate=2 February 2014|date=6 June 2013}}</ref>}} * {{Timeline-event |date='''{{Start date|1999|11|03}}''' |event= The [[BBC]] confirmed the existence of the global spying network [[ECHELON]]<ref name="echelon">{{cite news|last=Andrew Bomford|title=Echelon spy network revealed|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/503224.stm|publisher=BBC|date=3 November 1999 |accessdate= April 11, 2015}}</ref>}}
[[File:North face south tower after plane strike 9-11.jpg|thumb|center|The [[September 11 attacks]] on the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] led to major reforms of U.S. intelligence agencies, and paved the way for the establishment of the [[Director of National Intelligence]] position]]
* {{Timeline-event |date='''{{Start date|2005|12|16 }}''' |event= After withholding its publication for a year, ''[[The New York Times]]'' released an article under the following headline: "Bush Lets U.S. Spy on Callers Without Courts"<ref name="nytimes123">{{cite news |last1=Risen |first1=James |last2=Lichtblau |first2=Eric |title=Bush Lets U.S. Spy on Callers Without Courts|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/16/politics/16program.html?pagewanted=all|work=The New York Times|quote=The White House asked The New York Times not to publish this article|accessdate=August 14, 2013 |date=December 16, 2005}}</ref>}}
[[File:President Bush Speaking At Brooke Army Medical Center.jpg|thumb|center|On January 1, 2006, President Bush emphasized that "This is a limited program designed to prevent attacks on the United States of America. And I repeat, limited."<ref name="White House">{{cite web |date=January 1, 2006<!--, 12:05 PM CST -->|title=President Visits Troops at Brooke Army Medical Center|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2006/01/20060101.html |publisher=White House|accessdate=August 15, 2013}}</ref>]]
* {{Timeline-event |date='''{{Start date|2006|05|11 }}''' |event= ''[[USA Today]]'' reported that the NSA has a "massive database of Americans' phone calls"<ref name=USATODAY1/> }} Shortly afterwards, President Bush emphasized that the NSA's surveillance is limited and within the law<ref>{{cite news|last=JOHN O'NEIL|title=Bush Says U.S. Spying Is Not Widespread|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/05/11/washington/11cnd-phone.html|work=The New York Times|date=May 11, 2006 |accessdate= April 11, 2015}}</ref> * {{Timeline-event |date='''{{Start date|2013|06|06 }}''' |event= Britain's ''[[The Guardian]]'' newspaper reported that the NSA is "collecting phone records of millions of [[Verizon]] customers daily"<ref name="guardiangg621">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/06/nsa-phone-records-verizon-court-order |title=NSA collecting phone records of millions of Verizon customers daily |author=[[Glenn Greenwald]] |work=The Guardian |date=June 6, 2013 |deadurl=no |accessdate=September 16, 2013 |location=London}}</ref>}} [[File:US President Barack Obama, surveillance activities, June 2013.ogv|center|thumb|On June 7, 2013, President [[Barack Obama|Obama]] emphasized the importance of government surveillance to prevent [[Terrorism|terrorist attacks]]]] |}
=== 1970s === In 1972 NSA analyst [[Perry Fellwock]] (under the pseudonym "Winslow Peck") introduced the readers of ''[[Ramparts (magazine)|Ramparts]]'' magazine to the NSA and to the [[UKUSA Agreement]].<ref name="ramparts">{{cite news |title=U.S. Electronic Espionage: A Memoir |work=Ramparts |date=August 1972 |pages=35–50 |quote=The SIGINT community was defined by a TOP SECRET treaty signed in 1947. It was called the UKUSA treaty. The National Security Agency signed for the U.S. and became what's called First Party to the Treaty.}}</ref> In 1976, a separate article in ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]'' magazine revealed the existence of the [[GCHQ]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/aug/21/surveillance-secrecy-gchq |title=Surveillance secrecy: the legacy of GCHQ's years under cover |work=The Guardian |date=2013-08-21 |accessdate=2013-11-30 |author=Norton-Taylor, Richard |quote=GCHQ's cover was first blown in 1976 by an article, The Eavesdroppers, published by the London magazine, Time Out.}}</ref>
=== 1980s–1990s === In 1982 [[James Bamford]]'s book about the NSA, ''[[The Puzzle Palace]]'', was first published. Bamford's second book, ''[[Body of Secrets|Body of Secrets: Anatomy of the Ultra-Secret National Security Agency]]'', was published two decades later.
In 1988 the '''[[ECHELON]]''' network was revealed by [[Margaret Newsham]], a [[Lockheed Corporation|Lockheed]] employee. Newsham told a member of the U.S. Congress that the telephone calls of [[Strom Thurmond]], a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] U.S. senator, were being collected by the NSA. Congressional investigators determined that "targeting of U.S. political figures would not occur by accident. but was designed into the system from the start."<ref>{{citation |url=http://duncan.gn.apc.org/echelon-dc.htm |last=Campbell |first=Duncan |authorlink=Duncan Campbell (journalist) |title=Somebody's Listening |newspaper=New Statesman |date=1988-08-12 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420093650/http://duncan.gn.apc.org/echelon-dc.htm |archivedate=2013-04-20 |quote=The Congressional officials were first told of the Thurmond interception by a former employee of the Lockheed Space and Missiles Corporation, Margaret Newsham, who now lives in Sunnyvale, California.}}</ref>
By the late 1990s '''ECHELON''' was reportedly capable of monitoring up to 90% of all internet traffic.<ref name="bbcec"/> According to the [[BBC]] in May 2001, however, "The US Government still refuses to admit that Echelon even exists."<ref name="bbcec">{{cite news|title=Q&A: What you need to know about Echelon|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/sci/tech/1357513.stm|publisher=BBC|accessdate=18 December 2013|date=29 May 2001}}</ref>
=== 2000s === In the aftermath of the [[September 11 attacks]], [[William Binney (U.S. intelligence official)|William Binney]], along with colleagues [[J. Kirke Wiebe]] and [[Edward Loomis]] and in cooperation with House staffer [[Diane Roark]], asked the U.S. Defense Department to investigate the NSA for allegedly wasting "millions and millions of dollars" on [[Trailblazer Project|Trailblazer]], a system intended to analyze data carried on communications networks such as the Internet. Binney was also publicly critical of the NSA for spying on U.S. citizens after the [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001 attacks]].<ref>{{cite journal |last= Shorrock |first= Tim |authorlink= Tim Shorrock |title= The Untold Story: Obama's Crackdown on Whistleblowers: The NSA Four reveal how a toxic mix of cronyism and fraud blinded the agency before 9/11 |journal= The Nation |date= April 15, 2013 |url= http://www.thenation.com/article/173521/obamas-crackdown-whistleblowers }}</ref> Binney claimed that the NSA had failed to uncover the 9/11 plot despite its massive interception of data.<ref name="Mayer">{{cite journal |last= Mayer |first= Jane |authorlink= Jane Mayer |title= The Secret Sharer: Is Thomas Drake an enemy of the state? |journal= The New Yorker |date= May 23, 2011 |url= http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2011/05/23/110523fa_fact_mayer?currentPage=all }}</ref>
In 2001, after the September 11 attacks, [[MI5]] started collecting bulk telephone communications data in the United Kingdom on which telephone numbers called each other and when, authorised the [[Home Secretary]] under a little understood general power under the [[Telecommunications Act 1984]] instead of the [[Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000]] would have brought independent oversight and regulation. This was kept secret until announced by the then Home Secretary in 2015.<ref name=bbc-20151105>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-34731735 |title=How and why MI5 kept phone data spy programme secret |author=Gordon Corera |publisher=BBC |date=5 November 2015 |accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref><ref name=telegraph-20151104>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/11976008/MI5-and-GCHQ-secretly-bulk-collecting-British-publics-phone-and-email-records-for-years-Theresa-May-reveals.html |title=MI5 and GCHQ secretly bulk collecting British public's phone and email records for years, Theresa May reveals |author=Tom Whitehead |newspaper=Daily Telegraph |date=4 November 2015 |accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref><ref name=thereg-20151109>{{cite news |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2015/11/09/hawktalk_wip/ |title=Here's the little-known legal loophole that permitted mass surveillance in the UK |newspaper=The Register |date=9 November 2015 |accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref>
On December 16, 2005 ''[[The New York Times]]'' published a report under the headline "[[George W. Bush|Bush]] Lets U.S. Spy on Callers Without Courts", which was co-written by [[Eric Lichtblau]] and the [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning journalist [[James Risen]]. According to ''The Times'', the article's date of publication was delayed for a year (past the next presidential election cycle) because of alleged national security concerns.<ref name=nytimes2005>{{cite news|last=James Risen and Eric Lichtblau|title=Bush Lets U.S. Spy on Callers Without Courts|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/16/politics/16program.html|work=The New York Times|date=December 16, 2005 |accessdate= April 11, 2015}}</ref> [[Russ Tice]] was later revealed as a major source.
In 2006 further details of the NSA's domestic surveillance of U.S. citizens was provided by ''[[USA Today]]''. The newspaper released a report on May 11, 2006 detailing the NSA's "massive database" of phone records collected from "tens of millions" of U.S. citizens. According to ''USA Today'', these phone records were provided by several telecom companies such as [[AT&T]], [[Verizon Communications|Verizon]], and [[BellSouth]].<ref name=USATODAY1>{{cite news|last=Leslie Cauley|title=NSA has massive database of Americans' phone calls|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/washington/2006-05-10-nsa_x.htm|work=[USA Today|date=May 11, 2006 |accessdate= April 11, 2015}}</ref> AT&T technician [[Mark Klein]] was later revealed as major source, specifically of rooms at network control centers on the internet backbone intercepting and recording all traffic passing through. In 2008 the security analyst [[Babak Pasdar]] revealed the existence of the so-called "Quantico circuit" that he and his team had set up in 2003. The circuit provided the U.S. federal government with a [[Backdoor (computing)|backdoor]] into the network of an unnamed wireless provider, which was later independently identified as [[Verizon]].<ref name="Poulsen">{{cite news|last=Poulsen|first=Kevin|title=Whistle-Blower: Feds Have a Backdoor Into Wireless Carrier—Congress Reacts|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2008/03/whistleblower-f/|work=Wired|accessdate=August 14, 2013|date=March 6, 2008}}</ref>
In 2007 former [[Qwest]] CEO [[Joseph Nacchio]] alleged in court and provided supporting documentation that in February 2001 (nearly 7 months prior to the [[September 11 attacks]]) that the NSA proposed in a meeting to conduct blanket phone spying. He considered the spying to be illegal and refused to cooperate, and claims that the company was punished by being denied lucrative contracts.<ref>{{cite web |last = D'Andrade |first = Hugh |title = Qwest CEO: NSA Punished Qwest for Refusing to Participate in Illegal Surveillance--Pre-9/11! |work = Deeplinks blog |publisher = Electronic Frontier Foundation |date = October 17, 2007 |url = https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2007/10/qwest-ceo-nsa-punished-qwest-refusing-participate-illegal-surveillance-pre-9-11 |accessdate = 2015-05-21 |archiveurl = |archivedate = }}</ref>
=== 2010–2013 === In 2011 details of the [[mass surveillance industry]] were released by [[WikiLeaks]]. According to [[Julian Assange]], "We are in a world now where not only is it theoretically possible to record nearly all telecommunications traffic out of a country, all telephone calls, but where there is an [[mass surveillance industry|international industry]] selling the devices now to do it."<ref>{{cite news|title=Wikileaks disclosure shines light on Big Brother|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/wikileaks-disclosure-shines-light-on-big-brother/|publisher=CBS News|date=December 1, 2011 |accessdate= April 11, 2015}}</ref>
== Disclosures since 2013 == {{main|Global surveillance disclosures (2013–present)}}
== See also == * [[History of surveillance]] * [[NSA warrantless surveillance (2001–07)]] * [[Global surveillance whistleblowers]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Global surveillance disclosures (1970-2013)}} [[Category:Global surveillance]] [[Category:News leaks]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:Surveillance scandals]]

{{other ships|HMS Discovery}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use British English|date=January 2018}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=Resolution and Discovery.jpg |Ship image size=250px |Ship caption=''Resolution and Discovery'' by Samuel Adkin }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=United Kingdom |Ship flag=[[File:Naval Ensign of the United Kingdom.svg|60px|Royal Navy Ensign]] |Ship name=HMS ''Discovery'' |Ship ordered= |Ship builder=Langbourne, [[Whitby]] |Ship laid down= |Ship launched=1774 (as the [[Collier (ship type)|collier]] ''Diligence'') |Ship acquired=January 1776 |Ship commissioned=February 1776 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship honours= |Ship captured= |Ship fate=Broken up at [[Chatham Dockyard]] in October 1797 |Ship status= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class=8-gun discovery ship |Ship tons burthen=299 [[Builder's Old Measurement|bm]] |Ship length={{convert|91|ft|6|in|m|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|27|ft|6|in|m|abbr=on}} |Ship draught={{convert|11|ft|5|in|m|abbr=on}} |Ship hold depth= |Ship sail plan=[[brig]], later [[full rigged ship|full-rigged]] |Ship propulsion=sails |Ship complement=70 as transport |Ship armament=8 guns: |Ship notes= }} |}
'''HMS ''Discovery''''' was the consort ship of [[James Cook]]'s third expedition to the [[Pacific Ocean]] in 1776–1780. Like Cook's other ships, ''Discovery'' was a [[Whitby]]-built collier originally named ''Diligence'' when she was built in 1774. Purchased in 1775, the vessel was measured at 299 tons [[Builder's Old Measurement|burthen]].<ref>Colledge, p. 99.</ref> Originally a [[brig]], Cook had her changed to a [[full rigged ship]]. She was commanded by [[Charles Clerke]], who had previously served on Cook's first two expeditions, and had a complement of 70. When Cook was killed in a skirmish with natives of [[Hawaii]], Clerke transferred to the expedition's [[flagship]] [[HMS Resolution (1771)|HMS ''Resolution'']] and [[John Gore (Royal Navy captain)|John Gore]] assumed command of ''Discovery''. She returned to Britain under the command of Lieutenant [[James King (Royal Navy officer)|James King]], arriving back on 4 October 1780.
After returning to the [[Nore]] in 1780, ''Discovery'' was fitted out as a transport at [[Woolwich Dockyard]], serving as such between December 1780 and May 1781. She then became a dockyard craft at Woolwich, and was broken up at [[Chatham Dockyard]] in October 1797.
==See also== * [[European and American voyages of scientific exploration]] * [[Kidnapping of Kalaniʻōpuʻu by Captain James Cook]]
==References== {{Reflist}} *{{Colledge}} *Rif Winfield, British Warships in the Age of Sail, 1714-1792 (Seaforth Publishing, 2007). *[[John Cawte Beaglehole|Beaglehole, J.C.]]: ''The Life of Captain James Cook''. {{ISBN|0-8047-0848-7}}.
==External links== *[http://college.hmco.com/history/readerscomp/ships/html/sh_027200_hmsdiscover1.htm Ships of the World entry] * [http://badc.nerc.ac.uk/data/corral/ships/discovery_01.html Digitised copies of the original logs of HMS ''Discovery''], [http://badc.nerc.ac.uk British Atmospheric Data Centre]/[[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|The National Archives]] as part of [http://www.corral.org.uk/ the CORRAL project]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=April 2015}}
Hydraulic fracturing is the propagation of fractures in a [[Stratum|rock layer]] by pressurized fluid. Induced hydraulic fracturing or hydrofracking, commonly known as fracking, is a technique used to release petroleum, natural gas (including shale gas, tight gas and coal seam gas), or other substances for extraction.<ref name="Charlez"/> [[Radionuclides]] are associated with hydraulic fracturing in two main ways. Injection of man-made radioactive tracers, along with the other substances in hydraulic-fracturing fluid, is often used to determine the injection profile and location of fractures created by hydraulic fracturing.<ref name="Reis iodine" /> In addition, hydraulic fracturing releases naturally occurring heavy metals and radioactive materials from shale deposits, and these substances return to the surface with flowback, also referred to as wastewater.<ref name="Bucks Co Water" />
==Naturally occurring radionuclides==
{{main|Naturally occurring radioactive material}} There are naturally occurring radioactive material (e.g., [[radium]] and [[radon]]) in shale deposits.<ref name="Urbina 26Feb2011" /> Hydraulic fracturing can dislodge naturally occurring heavy metals and radioactive materials from shale deposits, and these substances return to the surface with flowback, also referred to as wastewater.<ref name="Urbina 26Feb2011" /><ref name="discover 08012011" /><ref name="TimesMap" /> These naturally occurring radionuclides are of more concern than some man-made radionuclides used in fracture monitoring because of their long half lives. Radium (Ra) is a product of [[Uranium-238]] decay, and is the longest-lived isotope of radium with a [[half-life]] of 1601 years; next longest is [[Radium-228]], a product of [[Thorium-232]] breakdown, with a half-life of 5.75 years.<ref name="nndc" /> Radon (Rn) is a naturally occurring product of the decay of [[uranium]] or [[thorium]]. Its most stable [[isotope]], [[Radon-222]], has a [[half-life]] of 3.8 days. [[Strontium]] is also naturally occurring and may be dislodged by the process.<ref name="discover 08012011" />
==Injected radionuclides==
Injection of radioactive tracers, along with the other substances in hydraulic-fracturing fluid, is often used to determine the injection profile and location of fractures created by hydraulic fracturing.<ref name="Reis iodine" /> Patents describe in detail how several tracers are typically used in the same well. Wells are hydraulically fractured in different stages.<ref name="No5635712" /> Tracers with different half-lives are used for each stage.<ref name="No5635712" /><ref name="US5441110"/> Their half-lives range from 40.2 hours ([[Lanthanum-140]]) to 28.90 years ([[Strontium-90]]).<ref name="ep0340956a1"/> Amounts per injection of radionuclide are listed in the US [[Nuclear Regulatory Commission]] (NRC) guidelines.<ref name="NRC"/> The NRC guidelines also list a wide range or radioactive materials in solid, liquid and gaseous forms that are used as field flood or enhanced oil and gas recovery study applications tracers used in single and multiple wells.<ref name="NRC"/> According to the NRC, some of the most commonly used include [[Antimony-124]], [[Bromine-82]], [[Iodine-125]], [[Iodine-131]], [[Iridium-192]], and [[Scandium-46]].<ref name="NRC"/> A 2003 publication by the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA) provides a detailed description of tracer use, confirms the frequent use of most of the tracers above, and says that [[Manganese-56]], [[Sodium-24]], Technetium-m, Silver-m, [[Argon-41]], and [[Xenon-133]] are also used extensively because they are easily identified and measured.<ref name="IAEA 2003" /> Other potentially suitable tracers are named in various patents.<ref name="No5635712" /><ref name="US5441110" /><ref name="US4415805" /> In terms of quantities used, the NRC gives the following examples: Iodine-131, gas form, 100 millicuries total, not to exceed 20 millicuries per injection; Iodine-131, liquid form, 50 millicuries total, not to exceed 10 millicuries per injection; Iridium-192, "Labeled" frac sand, 200 millicuries total, not to exceed 15 millicuries per injection; Silver-110m, liquid form, 200 millicuries total, not to exceed 20 millicuries per injection.<ref>[https://www.nrc.gov/reading-rm/doc-collections/nuregs/staff/sr1556/v14/#_1_26]</ref>
Other gamma-emitting tracer [[isotopes]] used are [[Antimony-121]], [[Antimony-122]], [[Antimony-123]], [[Antimony-125]], [[Antimony-126]], [[Antimony-127]], [[Carbon-14]], [[Chromium-51]], [[Cobalt-57]], [[Cobalt-58]], [[Cobalt-60]], [[Gold-198]], [[Iodine-127]], [[Iodine-128]], [[Iodine-129]], [[Iodine-130]], [[Iron-59]], [[Krypton-85]], [[Lanthanum-140]], [[Potassium-39]] (activated to [[Potassium-40]]), [[Potassium-41]] (activated to [[Potassium-42]]), [[Potassium-43]], [[Rubidium-86]], [[Scandium-45]], [[Scandium-47]], [[Scandium-48]], [[Silver-110]], [[Sodium-22]], [[Strontium-85]], [[Strontium-90]], [[Tritium]], [[Zinc-65]], and [[Zirconium-95]].<ref name="No5635712" /><ref name="US5441110" /><ref name="ep0340956a1" /><ref name="NRC" /><ref name="US4415805" />
==Environmental impact== Concerns have been expressed that both naturally occurring radionuclides and [[radioactive tracer]]s may return to the surface with flowback and during blow outs.<ref name="New Brunswick" /><ref name="NYSERDA" /> Wastewater from the wells is released into rivers, injected into wells, and evaporated from ponds.<ref name="Urbina 26Feb2011" /> ''The Times'' reported that studies by the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] and a confidential study by the drilling industry concluded that radioactivity in drilling waste cannot be fully diluted in rivers and other waterways.<ref name="toxic" /> Recycling the wastewater has been proposed as a solution but has its limitations.<ref name="Urbina 01Mar2011" /> ''[[The New York Times]]'' has reported on radium and gross alpha radiation levels in wastewater (also called flowback) from natural gas wells. It collected data from more than 200 natural gas wells in Pennsylvania. ''The New York Times'' has compiled a map of these wells and their wastewater contamination levels.<ref name="Urbina 26Feb2011" /><ref name="TimesMap" /><ref name="NYT" />
Political, governmental, and industry pressures have prevented the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) from studying risks associated with radionuclides<ref name="EPA re study"/> or other chemicals in hydraulic fracturing fluids in wastewater,<ref name="Chesapeake" /> source water, and drinking water.<ref name="EPA re study" /><ref name="NYT lobbying docs" /><ref name="TimesNaturalGasToxicGas" /><ref name="Urbina 03Mar2011" /><ref name="Research Council study2" /> The scope of the EPA Hydraulic Fracturing Draft Study Plan was narrowed to exclude them.<ref name="EPA re study"/><ref name="Urbina 03Mar2011" /><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120417160911/http://www.shalegas.energy.gov/resources/HFStudyPlanDraft_SAB_020711.pdf]</ref>
==Health impact== As radon decays, it produces radioactive decay products. If the contaminated dust of these "radon daughters" are inhaled, they can lodge in the lungs and increase the risk of developing lung cancer.<ref name="radon" /> Iodine in food is absorbed by the body and preferentially concentrated in the [[thyroid]] where it is needed for the functioning of that gland. When Iodine-131 is present in high levels in the environment from hydraulic fracturing flowback and blowouts, it can be absorbed through contaminated food and water, and will also accumulate in the thyroid. As it decays, it may cause damage to the thyroid. The primary risk from exposure to high levels of iodine-131 is the chance occurrence of [[radiogenic]] [[thyroid cancer]] in later life. Other risks include the possibility of non-cancerous growths and [[thyroiditis]].<ref name="Rivkees" /><ref name="radiation effects"/> The level of radiation in hydraulic fracturing wastewater has been measured to be as high as 18,035 pCi/L,<ref name="TimesMap" /> thousands of times the maximum allowed by the federal standard for drinking water,<ref name="Urbina 26Feb2011" /><ref name="TimesMap" /> and there are concerns about radiation exposure during spills and blowouts.<ref name="New Brunswick" /><ref name="NYSERDA" /> Long term exposure to low level radiation is associated with stochastic<ref name="EPA stochastic" /> health effects; the greater the exposure, the more likely the health effects are to occur.<ref name="EPA stochastic" /> A group of doctors from the United States have called for a moratorium on hydraulic fracturing until health effects are more thoroughly studied.<ref name="BW 19.01.2012" /><ref name="Bloomberg 11.01.2012" />
==Regulation== The US [[Nuclear Regulatory Commission]] (NRC) and approved state agencies regulate the use of injected radionuclides in hydraulic fracturing in the United States.<ref name="NRC"/> Federal and state regulators do not require sewage treatment plants that accept drilling waste to test for radioactivity. In Pennsylvania, where the hydraulic fracturing drilling boom began in 2008, most drinking-water intake plants downstream from those sewage treatment plants have not tested for radioactivity since before 2006.<ref name="taint" /> The EPA has asked the [[Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection]] to require community water systems in certain locations, and centralized wastewater treatment facilities to conduct testing for radionuclides.<ref name="EPA letter to PADEP" /><ref name="Urbina 07Mar2011" /> Safe drinking water standards have not yet been established to account for radioactivity levels of hydraulic fracturing waste water,<ref name="Urbina 26Feb2011" /> and although water suppliers are required to inform citizens of radon and other radionuclides levels in their water, this doesn't always happen.<ref name="Carbon County" /> Radioactive tracers are not yet listed on FracFocus,<ref>[http://fracfocus.org/ FracFocus]</ref> a website indicating chemical composition of fracking fluid of individual wells, but federal and state nuclear regulatory agencies keep records of their use.<ref name="NRC" />
==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= <ref name="Charlez">{{cite book |last=Charlez |first=Philippe A. |year=1997 |title=Rock Mechanics: Petroleum Applications |location=Paris |publisher=Editions Technip |url =https://books.google.com/books?id=NigwG_BYRsYC&pg=PA239| page = 239| accessdate = 2012-05-14}}</ref>
